case: A 26-year-old man presented to the emergency room complaining of sudden left sided chest pain for few hours. Clinical examination revealed contralateral tracheal shift and hyperresonance with absent breathing sound over the left lung. What is the most likely diagnosis? [10/2021T_2/2023S]

explanation.correct: Sudden unilateral chest pain with absent breath sounds, hyperresonance, and contralateral tracheal shift indicates tension pneumothorax on the left side due to accumulation of air under pressure in the pleural cavity.

incorrect.reason: Would cause dullness to percussion, bronchial breathing, and crepitations — not hyperresonance.
Usually secondary to pulmonary embolism and presents with hemoptysis, pleuritic pain, but not tracheal deviation or hyperresonance.
Causes central chest pain without respiratory findings or tracheal deviation.
Characterized by substernal pain and ECG changes, not unilateral absent breath sounds.

case: A 52-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 3-week history of shortness of breath and nonproductive cough. The shortness of breath has progressively worsened during the past 2 days. She also has a 3-week history of low back mild pain. Ibuprofen has provided minimal relief of her pain. She began smoking at age 32 and has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily. Her temperature is 37.0°C, pulse is 105/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 180/118 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88 %. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention to 3cm above the sternal angle. Auscultation of the lungs discloses bilateral wheezing and basilar crackles. Cardiac examination discloses an S3. There is bilateral edema of the lower extremities. Chest X-ray shows cardiomegaly, bilateral infiltrates, and bilateral pleural effusions at the lung base. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? [10/2021T_11/2022R_6/2023R]

explanation.correct: The presentation of progressive dyspnea, S3 gallop, pulmonary congestion, and cardiomegaly with bilateral pleural effusions suggests acute myocarditis causing biventricular heart failure. Often follows viral infection and can mimic decompensated heart failure.

incorrect.reason: Would present mainly with peripheral edema, ascites, and JVP elevation but without pulmonary edema or S3.
Causes wheezing but not S3, JVP elevation, or cardiomegaly.
Would show focal infiltrate, fever, and productive cough — not diffuse cardiomegaly or pleural effusions.
May cause dyspnea and wheeze, but not acute S3 gallop or bilateral pleural effusions.

case: A 25-year-old woman is brought to the Emergency Department following a road traffic car accident. On arrival her blood pressure is 110/50 mmHg, heart rate 92/min and respiratory rate 28/min. On examination there is decreased air entry on the right side as well as dullness on percussion and fracture of 2 ribs. Which one of the following is immediate treatment of the patient’s condition? [10/2021T_11/2022R_6/2023R_11/2023S_11/2023R_2/2024T_8/2024T]
options: Insertion of chest drain underwater seal
correctAnswer: Insertion of chest drain underwater seal

explanation.correct: The patient has hemothorax — dullness to percussion, decreased air entry, and rib fracture indicate blood in the pleural cavity. The immediate management is insertion of a chest tube with underwater seal drainage to evacuate blood and re-expand the lung.

incorrect.reason: Restricts ventilation and increases hypoxia risk.
Supportive only; does not treat the underlying hemothorax.
Only indicated if respiratory failure develops — not the initial step.
Contraindicated in thoracic trauma with possible pneumothorax/hemothorax.

case: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room with a 3-hour history of fever 39.5°C and sore throat. The child appears anxious and toxic. He has mild inspiratory stridor and he is drooling. He is sitting on the examination table leaning forward with his neck extended. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate management of the patient? [2/2023T_2/2023R_6/2023S_6/2023R]
options: Admit the child and place him in a mist tent
Examine the throat and obtain a culture
Obtain an arterial blood gas and start an IV line

explanation.correct: The clinical picture of high fever, drooling, tripod position, and inspiratory stridor is classic for acute epiglottitis — a life-threatening airway obstruction. The priority is immediate airway management by expert (endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy).

incorrect.option: Admit the child and place him in a mist tent
incorrect.reason: Delays definitive airway; mist tent is for mild croup, not epiglottitis.

incorrect.option: Examine the throat and obtain a culture
incorrect.reason: Can trigger laryngospasm and complete airway obstruction.

incorrect.option: Obtain an arterial blood gas and start an IV line
incorrect.reason: Secondary to airway stabilization; not initial.
Only after airway is secured; doing so before is dangerous.

case: A 31-year-old man is brought to the emergency room following a motor car accident in which his chest struck the steering wheel. Examination reveals stable vital signs, but the patient exhibits multiple palpable rib fractures and paradoxical movement of the right side of the chest. Chest X-ray shows no evidence of pneumo- or hemothorax but a large pulmonary contusion is developing. What is the proper management for this case? [1/2023M_2/2023T_2/2023R_6/2023S_6/2023R_11/2023S_11/2023R_8/2024T-8/2024R]
options: Stabilization of the chest wall with sandbags
Tracheostomy, mechanical ventilation and positive end-expiratory pressure
correctAnswer: Tracheostomy, mechanical ventilation and positive end-expiratory pressure

explanation.correct: Paradoxical chest movement indicates flail chest with underlying pulmonary contusion. The definitive management is airway protection and mechanical ventilation with positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) to stabilize the flail segment internally.

incorrect.option: Stabilization of the chest wall with sandbags
incorrect.reason: Temporary measure only; not adequate for pulmonary contusion.
Rarely required unless chest wall defect is massive.
Obsolete and inadequate.
Incorrect because mechanical ventilation is the standard of care.

case: A 52-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 3-week history of shortness of breath and nonproductive cough. The shortness of breath has progressively worsened during the past 2 days. She also has a 3-week history of low back mild pain. Ibuprofen has provided minimal relief of her pain. She has no history of serious illness and takes no routine medications. She began smoking at age 32 and smoked one pack of cigarettes daily. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6 F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 180/118 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention to 3 cm above the sternal angle. Auscultation of the lungs discloses bilateral wheezing and basilar crackles. Cardiac examination discloses an S3. There is bilateral edema of the lower extremities. Chest x-ray shows cardiomegaly, bilateral infiltrates, and bilateral pleural effusions at the lung base. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy? [10/2021T_11/2022R_6/2023R]

explanation.correct: The patient has acute decompensated left-sided heart failure with pulmonary edema. The first-line treatment is IV furosemide to reduce preload and pulmonary congestion rapidly.

incorrect.reason: Beta blockers are contraindicated in acute decompensated heart failure; only used chronically when stable.
Less effective than loop diuretics for acute pulmonary edema.
Acts slowly; used in chronic heart failure with atrial fibrillation.
Used when there is cardiogenic shock with poor perfusion, not isolated pulmonary edema.

case: A 39-year-old motorcyclist presents following a road traffic collision. He arrives at the Emergency Department with a pelvic splint in place. He is assessed with a primary survey, which discovers a likely pelvic fracture. He is tachycardic at 115 beats/min despite giving an immediate 2L of Hartmann’s solution. He is hypotensive on reassessment. What is the most appropriate management option? [11/2020T_12/2020T_1/2021T_11/2022R]

explanation.correct: Persistent hypotension after adequate fluid resuscitation in pelvic fracture indicates ongoing arterial bleeding. Selective internal iliac artery embolization is the best management to control pelvic hemorrhage.

incorrect.reason: Not indicated unless there is evidence of intraperitoneal bleeding.
Does not address hemodynamic instability.
No signs of thoracic injury.
Irrelevant to the source of bleeding.

case: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency room with abdominal pain and vomiting for 2 days. She is passing flatus but has not passed stools since yesterday. On examination the abdomen is tender with marked distension. There is a tender swelling above the umbilicus which is crescentic in shape. The swelling is irreducible, dark in color and does not give an impulse on coughing. The pulse rate is 108 bpm, blood pressure 90/50 and temperature is 38.0°C. What is the immediate management? [1/2023M_2/2023T_2/2023R_6/2023S_6/2023R_11/2023S_2/2024S_8/2024T_8/2024R]
options: Preoperative detailed investigations to detect the cause.

explanation.correct: The case is a strangulated paraumbilical hernia with obstruction and ischemia. Immediate surgical intervention is mandatory to release strangulation and resect devitalized bowel if needed.

incorrect.option: Preoperative detailed investigations to detect the cause.
incorrect.reason: Delays life-saving surgery in strangulation.
Important supportive step but not definitive management.
Not possible without surgery.
May be part of surgery but not the immediate overall management step.

case: A fully heparinized patient develops a condition requiring emergency surgery. After stopping the heparin, what else should be done to prepare the patient? [11/2022R_1/2023M_2/2023T_2/2023R_6/2023S-6/2023R_2/2024S_8/2024R]
options: Immediate administration of protamine 5 mg for every 100 units of heparin most recently administered.
Nothing, if the surgery can be delayed for 2-3 hours.
correctAnswer: Immediate administration of protamine 5 mg for every 100 units of heparin most recently administered.

explanation.correct: Protamine sulfate neutralizes the anticoagulant effect of heparin rapidly and is the specific antidote before emergency surgery.

incorrect.reason: Reverses warfarin, not heparin.

incorrect.option: Nothing, if the surgery can be delayed for 2-3 hours.
incorrect.reason: Heparin effect persists for several hours; neutralization is safer.
Platelet transfusion does not reverse heparin effect.
Used for factor deficiency or warfarin reversal, not heparin.

case: A 75-year-old male patient is brought to emergency room with sudden inability to pass urine. The patient gave history of frequency & micturition over the last few years which makes him wake up 2-3 times/night. Abdominal examination showed supra-pubic swelling. What is the diagnosis of this condition? [1/2023M_2/2023T_2/2023R_6/2023S_6/2023R-11/2023S_8/2024T_8/2024R]

explanation.correct: An elderly man with gradual lower urinary tract symptoms (frequency, nocturia) and acute urinary retention with palpable bladder suggests BPH causing bladder outlet obstruction.

incorrect.reason: Usually presents with weight loss, bone pain, and hard irregular prostate, not acute retention alone.
Associated with fever, flank pain, and dysuria, not palpable bladder.
Would present after pelvic trauma with blood at meatus.
More common in young males post-infection, presents with poor stream but not acute retention.

case: A 70-year-old man has been brought as an emergency complaining of sudden onset of severe left sided abdominal pain radiating to the back. He has a systolic blood pressure of 70 mmHg, pulse rate of 120 per minute and is cold and clammy with a tender distended abdomen and a pulsatile mass, which of the following is the appropriate diagnosis? [2/2023S]

explanation.correct: Elderly man with hypotension, back pain, and pulsatile abdominal mass = classic triad for ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA), a surgical emergency.

incorrect.reason: Occurs postoperatively with raised intraabdominal pressure, not sudden collapse.
Unrelated term; emboli cause limb ischemia not abdominal mass.
Presents with continuous bruit and high-output heart failure, not shock.
Causes lower limb ischemia, not abdominal distension or hypotension.

case: An 11-month-old boy is brought to the Emergency Department with 6 episodes of diarrhea and 4 episodes of vomiting daily for the past 2 days. On examination, he has a dry mouth, sunken eyes, and depressed fontanelle. What is the most important initial management step? [1/2023M_6/2023R_11/2023T_11/2023S_2/2024T_2/2024S_8/2024T_8/2024S]
options: Send home advising the mother for giving excess fluids
Insert IV line and correct dehydration
correctAnswer: Insert IV line and correct dehydration

explanation.correct: Signs of moderate to severe dehydration (sunken eyes, depressed fontanelle) require IV rehydration to restore fluid and electrolyte balance promptly.

incorrect.option: Send home advising the mother for giving excess fluids
incorrect.reason: Appropriate only for mild dehydration.
Does not correct dehydration.
Not indicated during acute dehydration management.
Contraindicated in children due to risk of ileus and toxicity.

case: An 18-month-old male is brought to the Emergency Department with diarrhea and vomiting for 2 days. He has about 6 episodes of diarrhea and 4 episodes of vomiting per day and is not feeding well. His mother states that his activity level is decreased, is always weak and tired and has a decreased number of wet diapers. What is the most important initial management step? [2/2021R_10/2021T_11/2022R_1/2023M_11/2023T_11/2023S-2/2024T_2/2024S_8/2024T]
options: Insert IV line to correct dehydration
Send home advising the mother to give excess fluids
correctAnswer: Insert IV line to correct dehydration

explanation.correct: The child has moderate to severe dehydration as evidenced by lethargy, dry mucosa, and oliguria — IV fluid therapy with isotonic solution is essential.

incorrect.reason: Symptomatic only; does not replace fluids.
Contraindicated in infants.

incorrect.option: Send home advising the mother to give excess fluids
incorrect.reason: Unsafe for moderate dehydration.
Feeding withheld until rehydration achieved.

case: A nine-month-old infant was brought to the Emergency Department with repeated attacks of watery diarrhea for the past 24 hours. On examination, he has slow skin pinch, mildly sunken eyes, irritability and his abdomen is lax and not distended. Which of the following is the most appropriate management step? [2/2021R_1/2021R_1/2023M_11/2023T_11/2023S-2/2024T_2/2024S_8/2024T_8/2024S]
options: Ryle tube administration of oral hydration solution

explanation.correct: The infant has mild dehydration (slow skin pinch, mild irritability). The best treatment is oral rehydration therapy (ORT) using WHO oral solution to prevent worsening.

incorrect.reason: Reserved for severe dehydration or shock.
Not urgent before rehydration in mild cases.

incorrect.option: Ryle tube administration of oral hydration solution
incorrect.reason: Used only if oral intake not tolerated.
Antidiarrheal drugs are contraindicated in infants.

case: A ten months old boy suddenly develops fever 40.1°C and is rushed by his parents to the Emergency Room. As soon as he arrives, he starts to convulse with tonic clonic fits. Respiratory rate 40/min, heart rate 110/min. Which is the most appropriate initial management step? [10/2021T_11/2022R_1/2023M_2/2023T_2/2023R_5/2023M_6/2023S_6/2023R]
options: Ensure patent airway and IV diazepam
correctAnswer: Ensure patent airway and IV diazepam

explanation.correct: Febrile seizure management starts with maintaining airway, breathing, and circulation, followed by administration of IV diazepam to terminate convulsions.

incorrect.reason: Fluids are supportive but airway takes priority.
Antibiotics are for infection later, not initial seizure control.
Used if IV access unavailable; airway still the first priority.
Lowers fever but does not stop seizure.

case: A severely traumatized woman is seen in the emergency room with a Glasgow coma scale of 5T. Her family asks what the significance of this measurement is. Which of the following statements you will say it to the family regarding the Glasgow coma scales of this patient? [10/2021T_11/2021R_6/2023R_2/2024T]
options: It includes measurement of intracranial pressure (ICP).
A high score correlates with a high mortality rate
It includes measurement of verbal response, motor response and eye opening.
It serves to assess the long-term sequelae of head trauma.
It includes measurement of pupillary reflexes.
correctAnswer: It includes measurement of verbal response, motor response and eye opening.

explanation.correct: The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) assesses three domains only: eye opening, verbal response, and motor response. A score of 5T indicates severe impairment with a recorded "T" for intubation (verbal not testable).

incorrect.option: It includes measurement of intracranial pressure (ICP).
incorrect.reason: ICP is not part of GCS; it requires invasive monitoring and is a separate parameter.

incorrect.option: A high score correlates with a high mortality rate
incorrect.reason: The opposite: higher GCS = better prognosis; lower GCS correlates with higher mortality.

incorrect.option: It serves to assess the long-term sequelae of head trauma.
incorrect.reason: GCS reflects current level of consciousness, not long-term outcomes.

incorrect.option: It includes measurement of pupillary reflexes.
incorrect.reason: Pupillary responses are part of neurologic exam but not included in GCS scoring.

case: A 75-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 8-hour history of left-sided abdominal pain. This morning 2 hours ago, she passed stool with dark-colored blood clots. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension treated with ACE inhibitors. She has no history of gastrointestinal illness. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/85 mm Hg. Abdominal examination discloses tenderness (pain) to palpation along the descending colon. Laboratory studies show: CT scan of the abdomen with contrast shows no free air. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the suspected diagnosis? [10/2021T_6/2023R]
options: CT scan of the abdomen with contrast

explanation.correct: Elderly patient with acute left-sided abdominal pain, fever, hematochezia, and descending colon tenderness is suspicious for ischemic colitis. Colonoscopy confirms the diagnosis by direct visualization of mucosal ischemia and allows biopsy if needed.

incorrect.reason: Contraindicated in suspected colitis/ischemia due to risk of perforation and poor yield acutely.

incorrect.option: CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
incorrect.reason: Useful for suggesting ischemia or complications, but colonoscopy is the confirmatory test.
Low sensitivity for colonic mucosal ischemia.
Not first-line and rarely needed to confirm ischemic colitis.

case: A 65-year-old female patient is admitted to the emergency department with a short history of fresh blood per rectum, and long history of altered bowel habits. The patient is pale, blood pressure: 140/85, Pulse: 75/min. There are residual stains of blood on rectal examination. Her bowel is opened with no new attacks of bleeding. What is the next immediate step for management? [10/2021T_6/2023R_2/2024S]

explanation.correct: In a hemodynamically stable patient with lower GI bleeding and history suggesting colonic pathology, colonoscopy is the next step to localize the bleeding source and evaluate for neoplasia or colitis.

incorrect.reason: Poor at localizing colonic bleeding or mucosal lesions.
Evaluates upper GI tract; presentation indicates a lower source.
Most useful in brisk ongoing bleeding; here bleeding has subsided and the patient is stable.
Limited diagnostic value for lower GI bleeding.

case: A 60-year-old woman comes to the emergency department 2 hours after she vomited coffee ground-like material. She has no history of similar symptoms. She has osteoarthritis of both hips and hypertension. She is on daily non-steroidal, anti-inflammatory tablet and Enalapril tablet. She started smoking at age 30 and has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily She drinks one glasses of wine once a week. She is 160 cm tall and weighs 85 kg. Her temperature is 36.9°C, pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no other abnormalities. Nasogastric aspiration yields 200 ml of coffee-ground material. A 0.9% saline stomach lavage cleared the aspirate. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis? [10/2021T_6/2023R]

explanation.correct: Coffee-ground emesis indicates upper GI bleeding that has slowed; the diagnostic test of choice is urgent upper endoscopy to identify and potentially treat the source (e.g., NSAID-related peptic ulcer).

incorrect.reason: Not useful for mucosal bleeding source localization in the upper GI tract.
Does not evaluate the esophagus/stomach mucosa.
Assesses motility disorders, not bleeding.
Reserved for active brisk bleeding when endoscopy fails or is not feasible.

case: 44-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a - day history of severe pain in her upper abdomen that radiates to her back, nausea, and vomiting. She has had 3 episodes of emesis during this time. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She does not smoke cigarettes. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 11/min, respirations are 22/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 118/72 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. The abdomen is soft and mildly distended. There is severe right upper quadrant and epigastric tenderness (pain) to palpation. No organomegaly is noted. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the suspected diagnosis? [10/2021T_11/2022R_6/2023R]
options: CT scan of the abdomen with contrast

explanation.correct: Severe RUQ/epigastric pain radiating to the back suggests biliary pathology (e.g., acute cholecystitis/biliary colic). Right upper quadrant ultrasound is the best initial and confirmatory test for gallstones, wall thickening, and sonographic Murphy’s sign.

incorrect.reason: HIDA can help if ultrasound is equivocal, but ultrasound is first-line.

incorrect.option: CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
incorrect.reason: CT is less sensitive for gallstones and not first choice for suspected cholecystitis.
Assesses mucosa; not for biliary disease diagnosis.
Evaluates cardiac structures, unrelated to biliary pain.

case: A two-year-old boy is rushed by his mother to the Emergency Room with difficult breathing and coughing for the last 2 days. Temperature is 37° C, Respiratory Rate 34/min, HR 100/min. Examination reveals diminished air entry and wheezes on the right side of the chest only. Chest X-ray reveals over distended right lung, especially in expiratory film. What is the most appropriate next management step? [10/2021T_6/2023R_11/2023T_2/2024S_2/2024R]
options: Use a nebulizer with beta 2 agonist

explanation.correct: Unilateral wheeze with hyperinflation on expiratory film is classic for inhaled foreign body causing ball-valve obstruction. Urgent rigid bronchoscopy is both diagnostic and therapeutic.

incorrect.option: Use a nebulizer with beta 2 agonist
incorrect.reason: May transiently improve wheeze but does not remove the obstruction.
Not definitive and delays urgent removal.
Symptomatic only; foreign body remains.
Ineffective and potentially harmful with airway obstruction by foreign body.

case: A 56-year-old man presents to the emergency department complaining of a change in skin color, fatigue, discomfort in his hand joints, and abdominal pain. He has also noticed increased urine output and thirst. On examination, his skin appears bronze in color, his liver span is 16 cm, and there is loss of body hair, and testicular atrophy. His ferritin is 600 ng/mL (15-200 ng/mL), aspartate aminotransferase (AST) 130 U/L (8-20 U/L), alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 150 U/L (8-20 U/L), and total bilirubin 0.5 mg/dL (0.1-1 mg/dL). Coagulation tests and albumin level are normal, but the random glucose is elevated at 250 mg/dL. What are the expected hormonal results in this patient? [2/2021R_1/2023M_5/2023M_11/2023T_2/2024T_2/2024R]

explanation.correct: Classic triad of bronze skin, hepatomegaly, and diabetes ("bronze diabetes") with very high ferritin indicates hereditary hemochromatosis due to iron overload causing endocrine (hypogonadism, diabetes) and hepatic involvement.

incorrect.reason: Copper metabolism disorder presents with low ceruloplasmin, neurologic signs, and Kayser–Fleischer rings, not bronze skin and high ferritin.
Hyperpigmentation with hypotension and hyponatremia; does not explain high ferritin or hepatomegaly from iron overload.
Can cause organ dysfunction but not bronze pigmentation with elevated iron indices.
Explains hyperglycemia only; does not account for systemic iron overload signs.

case: A 26-year-old man presents at the emergency department with sudden onset breathlessness. Examination shows him to be dyspneic at rest, with saturations of 80% on room air and a pulse rate of 100 beats/min. His trachea is not deviated, and his blood pressure is 117/82 mm Hg. X-ray revealed a pneumothorax. After administering oxygen, what is the next step of management? [10/2021T_2/2021R_11/2021R_11/2022R_1/2023M-5/2023M_11/2023T_2/2024T_8/2024S]

explanation.correct: Symptomatic pneumothorax with hypoxemia (SpO2 80% on air) requires definitive decompression with intercostal chest tube to re-expand the lung after supplemental oxygen.

incorrect.reason: No role in pneumothorax management.
For pulmonary edema, not pneumothorax.
Contraindicated; positive pressure may worsen the pneumothorax.
Treats bronchospasm, not intrapleural air.

case: You review a 24-year-old woman with a history of asthma in the Emergency Department. She has been admitted with acute shortness of breath associated with tongue tingling and an urticarial rash after eating a meal containing shellfish. Her symptoms settle with nebulized salbutamol and intravenous hydrocortisone. What is the most useful test to establish whether this episode was due to anaphylaxis? [10/2020T_11/2020T_1/2023M_6/2023S]

explanation.correct: Serum tryptase, measured within 1–2 hours of the event, reflects mast cell degranulation and supports anaphylaxis diagnosis when elevated.

incorrect.reason: Total IgE is nonspecific; specific IgE tests are for allergies but do not confirm acute anaphylaxis.
Rises and falls rapidly within minutes; low sensitivity and timing dependent.
May be elevated in atopy but not diagnostic of anaphylaxis.
Marker of inflammation/infection, not for anaphylaxis.

case: A 25 year-old professional football player has sudden pain and swelling in the right groin when attempting to intercept a pass. He is admitted to the local emergency department. On examination, there is a tender swelling in the right groin. The scrotum and penis show no abnormality. What is the next step in management? [12/2020T_11/2022R]
options: Preoperative preparation and exploration of the groin with hernia repair
correctAnswer: Preoperative preparation and exploration of the groin with hernia repair

explanation.correct: Acute tender groin swelling after exertion is concerning for incarcerated/strangulated inguinal hernia. Definitive management is urgent operative exploration and hernia repair.

incorrect.reason: Risks injury and infection; does not address a strangulated hernia.
May reduce necrotic bowel into the abdomen (reduction en masse) and is contraindicated with tenderness and suspected strangulation.
Inguinal approach is appropriate; midline laparotomy is unnecessary unless peritonitis or uncertain diagnosis.
Delays definitive care, increasing risk of ischemia.

case: A7-year-old boy brought to the emergency room with generalized urticarial rash 15-minutes following ingestion of nuts. Which of the following is a clinical manifestation of anaphylactic shock? [11/2023T_2/2024S]

explanation.correct: Anaphylaxis is a systemic hypersensitivity reaction; distributive shock from massive vasodilation manifests as hypotension, often with urticaria and airway symptoms.

incorrect.reason: Nonspecific; may occur but does not define shock.
Contrary to the vasodilatory physiology of anaphylaxis.
Skin is often warm/flushed in distributive shock; cool clammy skin is more typical of hypovolemia.
Nonspecific and not a hemodynamic manifestation of shock.

case: A 4-year-old boy brought to the emergency room with flushed skin, after he received an intramuscular injection of antibiotic. Which of the following is a clinical manifestation of anaphylaxis? [12/2020T_12/2021T_11/2023S_11/2023R_2/2024T_8/2024T_8/2024S]

explanation.correct: Hypotension due to systemic vasodilation and increased vascular permeability is a hallmark of anaphylaxis.

incorrect.reason: Nonspecific and not diagnostic of anaphylaxis with shock.
Opposite of expected hemodynamic change in anaphylaxis.
More typical of hypovolemic shock; anaphylaxis often shows warm, flushed skin early.
May occur but is not a defining hemodynamic sign.

case: A 44-year-old woman, with a history of depression, presents to the emergency department complaining of feeling unwell with headaches and blurred vision. She says the headaches have been getting worse over the last two weeks and seem to be worse in the mornings. Her pulse is 40bpm and her blood pressure (BP) is 190/110 mmHg. Fundoscopy reveals bilateral swollen discs and there is diplopia on lateral gaze bilaterally, which of the following is the best next step in her management? [11/2021R_11/2022R_11/2023S_11/2023R_8/2024T_8/2024S]
options: Request an urgent CT of the brain
Perform a lumbar puncture and measure the CSF pressure
correctAnswer: Request an urgent CT of the brain

explanation.correct: Morning headaches, bradycardia with hypertension (Cushing response), papilledema, and cranial nerve VI palsies indicate raised intracranial pressure. The immediate step is urgent neuroimaging (CT) to exclude mass effect before any LP.

incorrect.option: Perform a lumbar puncture and measure the CSF pressure
incorrect.reason: Contraindicated before imaging in suspected raised ICP due to risk of herniation.
Empiric for suspected meningitis/encephalitis, which is not the leading concern here.
Steroids may be used for vasogenic edema from tumor but imaging must precede targeted therapy.
Useful later; CT is faster and adequate for initial evaluation of mass effect.

case: A 66-year-old man with rheumatoid arthritis was sent to accident and emergency by his general practitioner with a history of sudden severe upper abdominal pain, which started centrally in the epigastrium and spread across the upper abdomen. On examination he was in obvious pain, was normotensive but tachycardic and had board-like rigidity of the abdomen. A chest radiograph revealed free gas under the right hemidiaphragm. There was no other relevant previous history. What is the specific treatment advised for this patient? [11/2021R_11/2022R_2/2024S_8/2024S]
options: LV glucose and proton pump inhibitors.
Suturing the perforated duodenum and omental patch.
correctAnswer: Suturing the perforated duodenum and omental patch.

explanation.correct: Free intraperitoneal air with peritonitis indicates a perforated peptic ulcer. The standard operation is primary closure of the duodenal perforation with a Graham omental patch, plus lavage and PPI therapy.

incorrect.reason: Excessive for an acute perforated duodenal ulcer without malignancy.

incorrect.option: LV glucose and proton pump inhibitors.
incorrect.reason: Supportive; does not address the perforation surgically.
Adjuncts only; definitive repair is required.

case: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department complaining of weakness. On examination, his blood pressure is 85/46 mmHg, and his heart rate is 89 beats/min. case: A 40-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden severe chest pain radiating to the back between the scapulae. The pain began 1 hour ago while he was at rest. case: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden severe epigastric pain radiating to the back. The pain started 4 hours ago after a heavy meal. case: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath and sharp pleuritic chest pain that began suddenly while watching TV. She is on oral contraceptive pills. case: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency room with multiple stab wounds to the left chest. case: A 68-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe shortness of breath and pink frothy sputum. He has a history of hypertension and ischemic heart disease. case: A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency room after a road traffic accident. He is conscious but has severe abdominal pain and tenderness. Blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg and pulse 130/min. case: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of shortness of breath and pleuritic chest pain. She has been on bed rest for 10 days following knee surgery. case: A 70-year-old man with a history of ischemic heart disease and atrial fibrillation presents to the emergency department with sudden severe abdominal pain. case: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being rescued from a house fire. He is conscious but confused. He has singed nasal hairs, facial burns, and carbonaceous sputum. case: A 60-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is brought to the emergency room with severe shortness of breath and confusion. incorrect.reason: High-flow oxygen may worsen CO2 retention by reducing hypoxic drive.

case: A 77-year-old man presents to the emergency department complaining of dizziness and tiredness. On direct questioning he tells you she has recently been having black stools. case: A 3-month-old male comes to the emergency room with a history of upper respiratory symptoms for 3 days, fever, decreased appetite and increased work of breathing. case: A 32-year-old woman para 0+4 presented to emergency department at 30 weeks of her pregnancy. She was complaining of left lower limb swelling and pain. Duplex revealed DVT of left lower limb. Which of the following is the first priority in caring for this patient? [2/2024R]#

case: A 54-year-old man presents to the ED with acute onset of severe abdominal pain. His history is significant for gnawing epigastric pain that radiates to the back for several months. case: A 58-year-old woman came to the Emergency Room (ER) for evaluation of a painful left foot. She noticed the pain when she awoke in the morning. case: A 39-year-old woman comes to the emergency room because of right upper quadrant pain. case: A 25-year-old woman presents to the emergency room complaining of redness and pain in her right foot up to the level of the midcalf. case: A 48-year-old woman develops pain in the right lower quadrant while playing tennis. case: A 39-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of right lower quadrant abdominal pain and vaginal spotting. case: A 2-year-old girl with a ventricular septal defect (VSD) presents to the emergency department after a 15-minute focal seizure of her left arm and leg.
